												5/10While I'm giving this game a negative review I wanted it to be known that I do like the game and I really didn't notice these issues as glaringly until I when acheivement hunting. There are two main complains I have, the controls and the level design. I'll start with the controls even tho they are rather small issues.I played with a gamepad and it worked rather smoothly other than a few occasions where I couldn't jump for some reason in a platformer this is a rather large issue but as quickly as the came they pass I could honestly blame the controller as much as the game for this but it happened enough that I began to notice it. Other than that the controls worked like a charm on a controller. Level Design 1:This is my biggest complain, upon speed running the game (90 minutes or under) I noticed that everything in the game seemed more likely to be placed there simply to slow you down rather than for a functional reason. Example being on a level where you ride a mount across roughly open fields with some ruins you have to jump or break through you come to a area where you have to dismount and turn off a set of pipes dropping sludge down into a mesh covered hole then get back on the mount and continue on. On my first play through I gave it little though but upon replaying it I found myself asking why it was even there. the pipes seemed to just come fromm the sky and pour into a hole in the ground, even accepting sky pipes pumping down to the empty field why did I have to entire this waystation turn it off (not even a minute spent in the area mind you) other than to get by it which I could easily have just stepped 2 feet infront of it and bypassed it completely. After this I noticed it more and more in other levels where they did the same thing at one point later in the same level you get off your mount to clear a obstacles and the mount literally enters the foreground and runs off so once you finish the little minute long section its waiting for you on the other side. Being that you have no pactical reason to not just skip that entire area like your mount just did. Level Design 2:There is a level where you have to jump across a sludge river (lack of a better term) by jumping from one pole to the next, the area warns you it has instadeath. Upon falling in the sludge I found myself taking damage but not insta death Which lead me to question why I'm running from the pipe dropping it that is progressing after me. Out of curiousity I jumped into it and insta died. My only real problem when this is why is it that only the falling sludge insta deaths me, its the same sludge on the ground as falling but the ground sludge is just a damage over time effect. Shouldn't both have either instadeath or dot damage?Level Design 3:As with complain number 1 tasks seem forced at more than one point you have to time laser crossings but they are along major paths that every day works and soldiers would be using which leads me to ask why they practically exist there? I know I'm probably thing too much into it but at one point there is a laser cannon on a workers path way aimed at a guard station so that if you trip a alarm you can activate it to have it cut down the gaurds exitting the guard station. Why would  the guards allow them to set that up there?Level Design 4:There are very few of these but they are annoying, megaman wall jump sections. The couple I found gave me trouble which is probably why I disliked them but once again why are they needed? You can climb on almost everything in the game stucking to extremes in some cases. In all these areas they are "metal pipes" yet earlier and later in the same level you can climb other metal pipes just fine. I'm not seeing why these few (probably under 5) even exist other than to slow you down. Level Design 5:This is a akward one because I liked it at first. The games combat can be daunting even difficult until you release its pointless. On my first play through of stage 1 I fought every enemy I explored every nook and cranny it took me almost as long to beat this first level as it did for the entire speed run (55 minutes of 90) Did I enjoy it yes and found that it seemed like it was either a super long stage or there it didn't have stages and the "check points" (nicely placed I might add) were its way of saving. Upon speed running it I found if I just leaped over the enemies and didn't take too many wrong turns I could complete the level in 6-9 minutes (almost all the levels except the 2 that can be beaten in under 3 minutes) Which leads me back to level design 1 above. The enemies and combat system and nice, although they are basically red ranged soldier, red melee soldier, white ranged soldier, and white melee soldier (with a couple exceptions). Once I realised you didn't have any real need to fight them I questioned there existance, but they do actually pertain to the plot and seem to fit the world nicely. Which leads me to ask why then didn't they just make the force fights? That you couldn't progress until you fought atleast some of the enemies. I ran into only 3-5 of these which can mostly be skipped by not setting off a alarm. The 3 bosses where fun to fight and made me appericate the work the put into them to make them so different and have special ways to beat them. tl:dr I know people will say i'm over thinking it or what fun is a game without obstacles in your path, things to make you go out of your way to do. I understand this and accept it its just in this game every time one of these is placed there it seems almost glaringly so just to hinder the player rather than to fuctionally exist in there world as well. After I started to notice all of this I started looking at the game completely differently. I still enjoy the game and will buy episode 2. So i'm not saying Run away and don't play this game. I actually like it.

												This is a platforming, beat 'em up game that doesn't quite get either aspect right. None of the platforming is really that tricky, and there are no (or so few I've forgotten about them) bottomless pits and such, so the platforming isn't dangerous. And the super narrow perches you sometimes need to land on avoid being frustrating by automatically landing on them when you jump in their vicinity, which is almost worse, because it removes all of the challenge (except the challenge of getting caught in a wierd bug where you're suspended midair). Starting off the game with double jump and the ability to wall/ceiling climb on pretty much everything provides an opportunity to explore the rather large levels, but this is slightly hampered by lack of direction, which means you don't know if you're about to find an optional collectible, or just the next part of the stage. On top of this, there are times when progressing beyond certain points cuts you off from backtracking without warning.As for the combat, the character controls a floating sword that follows her around, which is a small departure from conventional combat. Your basic attacks are a flurry of short range attacks, which you can direct in pretty much any direction around you, or a slightly slower flurry of long range attacks that are limited to more or less straight left and right. The blade strikes can pass through platforms, which makes for a safe way to dispatch enemies on platforms above you. The long range attack can also stab enemies and draw them closer, although it doesn't necessarily prevent them from attacking you in that half-second between releasing them and starting the follow up attack. There is also a ground-pound type of attack which is powerful, if a little slow, and sliding does damage as well (often taking out enemies more quickly than the sword). The problem is there is a very limited selection of enemies, so the combat, which isn't super interesting to begin with, quickly becomes very boring (at least, when it's not frustrating you with suprisingly long stun-lock attacks from enemies).There is a story. I have no idea what it is. There are cutscenes between each level presumably letting you know what's going on, but the events and the protagonist's motivation are so loosely connected throughout that I have no idea what the current goal is, much less the end one. Repeatedly I feel like I've been thrown into an existing universe/franchise that makes zero effort to explain any context. One level begins in a ruined city with the protagonist seeing an alien and exclaiming "Not Darques! Not here!" That's all the explanation you get. It's apparently a horror themed level, because at various points you get brief nightmarish cutscenes, and the level ends with you getting after falling into a pit of the creatueres, you get KO'ed, but somehow wake up in a merchant camp outdoors to start the next level. A different level has you deliver a message to the commander of the mooks that have been your nearly exclusive enemies to that point, because, they're being attacked by someone else? And some of them will still attack you anyway.Have I mentioned yet that the money you collect throughout the game is used in a second pause menu that the game doesn't tell you about until four levels in? This whole game feels like a whole bunch of half thought out ideas mashed together.

												A mostly good game.Sure, it is somewhat floaty, and I've encountered a glitch or two, the combat generally isn't great, but I love this game.The graphics are a nice faux anime mixed with their own distinct style. All in what I think is cel-shading, though I could be wrong about the that. The battles tend to come down to button mashing, but that doesn't get in the way of fun as it's mostly a platformer, and a pretty great one, focusing highly on treasure collection, and if you want, you can jump over and ignore quite a few of the enemies. There are 19 levels, many of which are huge, but if you don't want to explore the first time around, you can get through them pretty quickly and go back later for secrets and treasure.  One thing I haven't seen before in a platformer  is the ability to climb walls, for you see, our protagonist is a catgirl.Of course, treasure collection is pointless without a way to spend treasure, so there's an ingame store that allows you to buy health and stamina upgrades, blades(get the strongest one for the least button mashing) and costumes, all with ingame money of course. This store can be accessed at any time once you've met the owner for the first time. There are a lot of costumes, and I do mean a LOT.The writing is pretty good, even if it does tend to suffer a bit from mood whiplash. The whole thing has a nice, witty sense of humor, especially when the protagonist, Kit Ballard, has to deal with Kreel, except when it's suddenly serious time.I very much reccommend this game. See if you can spot the Ty the Tasmanian Tiger references for extra fun.

												An example of high quality production. The writing for the game is witty and with great humor and care, with great graphics and music. The game has a bunch of interesting traits such exploration for collectibles to increase a completion percentage and a simple, yet functional combat system with moves like controllable angle short range slashes, middle range slashes, low, sliding kick attacks, a jump and dive slash and others that let you adapt to changing circumstances and enemies. it's not slash, slash, slash, jump, slash again. The story presentation is done through animated cutscenes instead of stills or simply the in-game character models. The voice acting is also excellent, which makes for watching them a much more enjoyable experience.The game can feel a bit short, but the amount of unlockables and exploration greatly make this game worthy of revisits and its replayability makes it much more inviting.Give it a good shot. Play the demo or jump straight into the game. This is a game that has much more heart in every piece that comprises it than many other rehashed game entries we see year after year.The second episode has been released in the form of DLC. This adds a few more stages and more achievements, with a final boss that is the right amounts of tricky, difficult and requiring of a proper strategy to defeat. And for the price the game is at, it's almost absurd not to, considering the amount of work that has gone into it. Amply recommended.

												Being a platformer lover as I am, I loved this the moment I played it. Based on the Blade Kitten comic (fans can buy the 3 already published issues or read them online in the game's website, with a new page being uploaded every week), this is a 2.5D (3D scenarios and characters, 2D gameplay) action platformer with great physics and lighting, an engaging story and lots of humour. As you advance in the game, you will be allowed to buy new swords and costumes, which will even reflect in cutscenes. The colours, the backgrounds, Kit's animations and the game replayability (you'll always wonder where is that secret you missed on this stage, or how cute/badass will Kit look while performing this attack, or in that cutscene) made me wonder when Blade Kitten Episode 2 would be released.Although it is fully playable with a keyboard, I recommend a game controller. It does not even have to be an expensive, new-generation gamepad, my PSOne Dual Shock worked perfectly for me!
